Line 3: Line 3:
==Early life==
==Early life==
â
Pauline was born in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] as Harriet Wood, and moved with her family to live in [[Michigan]]. At the age of eighteen she decided she should go to [[New York City|New York]] to become an actress, where she changed her name to Cushman – a tribute, it is thought, to [[Charlotte Cushman]], a famous actress of the period whom she admired. She pursued the craft mainly in the [[Southern United States|South]] with little success, but she met and married with a musician named Charles Dickinson in New Orleans, and went to live with his family in [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], where they had two children, Charles and Ida. Charles Senior was called to the war on the Union side and died in December 1862 as a result of the hostilities.She said," I'm a dum dum dumd umd head"""""".Dorkyface
+
Pauline was born in [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] as Harriet Wood, and moved with her family to live in [[Michigan]]. At the age of eighteen she decided she should go to [[New York City|New York]] to become an actress, where she changed her name to Cushman – a tribute, it is thought, to [[Charlotte Cushman]], a famous actress of the period whom she admired. She pursued the craft mainly in the [[Southern United States|South]] with little success, but she met and married with a musician named Charles Dickinson in New Orleans, and went to live with his family in [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], where they had two children, Charles and Ida. Charles Senior was called to the war on the Union side and died in December 1862 as a result of the hostilities.
==Spy==
==Spy==
Line 13: Line 13:
She lost both her children to sickness by 1868, and married again in 1872 in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], but was widowed within a year. Sources state that in 1879 she met Jere Fryer and moved to [[Casa Grande, Arizona|Casa Grande]], [[Arizona Territory]], where they married and operated a hotel and livery stable. He became the [[sheriff]] of [[Pinal County, Arizona|Pinal County]]. An adopted daughter died, and they separated in 1890. By 1892 she was living in poverty in [[El Paso, Texas]]. She had applied for back [[pension]] based on her first husband's military service, which was granted in June 1893. Her last days were spent in a boarding house in San Francisco, working as a seamstress and charwoman. Disabled from the effects of [[rheumatism]] and [[arthritis]], she became hooked on pain medicine, and on the night of the 1st of December 1893 she took an overdose of [[opium]], and was found the next morning by her landlady.
She lost both her children to sickness by 1868, and married again in 1872 in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], but was widowed within a year. Sources state that in 1879 she met Jere Fryer and moved to [[Casa Grande, Arizona|Casa Grande]], [[Arizona Territory]], where they married and operated a hotel and livery stable. He became the [[sheriff]] of [[Pinal County, Arizona|Pinal County]]. An adopted daughter died, and they separated in 1890. By 1892 she was living in poverty in [[El Paso, Texas]]. She had applied for back [[pension]] based on her first husband's military service, which was granted in June 1893. Her last days were spent in a boarding house in San Francisco, working as a seamstress and charwoman. Disabled from the effects of [[rheumatism]] and [[arthritis]], she became hooked on pain medicine, and on the night of the 1st of December 1893 she took an overdose of [[opium]], and was found the next morning by her landlady.
â
She had died as Peter at the age of sixty. The time of her Civil War fame was recalled at her funeral(idiot), which was arranged by members of the [[Grand Army of the Republic]]. "Major" Cushman's remains now rest in Officer's Circle at the [[San Francisco National Cemetery|Presidio's National Cemetery]] in San Francisco. Her simple gravestone recognizes her contribution to the Union's victory. It is marked, "Pauline C. Fryer, Union Spy."
+
She had died as Pauline Fryer at the age of sixty. The time of her Civil War fame was recalled at her funeral, which was arranged by members of the [[Grand Army of the Republic]]. "Major" Cushman's remains now rest in Officer's Circle at the [[San Francisco National Cemetery|Presidio's National Cemetery]] in San Francisco. Her simple gravestone recognizes her contribution to the Union's victory. It is marked, "Pauline C. Fryer, Union Spy."
